awd_titl_txt: Uncovering the mechanisms driving co-flowering community assembly: integrating flowering and floral trait distribution patterns via a novel use of network analysis
awd_abstract_narration:
To predict how environmental change will impact the long-term stability and species composition of plant communities it is critical to understand the ecological processes that determine community membership. This research will evaluate the combined importance of two ecological processes operating simultaneously in multi-species communities. First, competition between plant species for pollinators may result in the loss of the inferior competitor. Second, facilitation may cause both species to receive more pollinator visits and result in species co-occurrence. By measuring pollinator visits and flower traits attractive to pollinators the researchers will quantify the simultaneous action of competition and facilitation. These data will allow the researchers to better understand patterns of species coexistence and community composition. This research will also advance the science education of under-represented groups and first-generation college students in the Appalachian region. In addition, outreach activities associated with pollinator gardens at nature centers will increase awareness of pollination as a key ecosystem service.
The project will use network analysis to identify co-flowering and floral-trait modules within serpentine seep communities in California. Observed modularity will be used to predict the roles of competitive and facilitative pollinator interactions as drivers of species assembly. The researchers propose that the distribution of flowering phenology and floral traits in a community are determined by: 1) the strength and direction of plant-plant interactions via pollinator visitation, and 2) the fitness cost of direct plant-plant interactions via interspecies pollen transfer. These predictions will be experimentally tested in the field by manipulating co-flowering community composition and in the greenhouse via hand pollination experiments with pure and mixed-pollen loads. The researchers make two predictions. First, species membership in different co-flowering modules is the result of competitive plant-plant interactions via pollinators. Second, species membership in the same co-flowering module can result from facilitative, competitive, or both types of interactions acting simultaneously. This research will help take our understanding of co-flowering community assembly from a descriptive to a more predictive stage.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
A $699,797 NSF Grant (DEB 1931163) was awarded to our research team at East Tennessee State University to study the processes that shape the plant communities that we observe and enjoy in nature. Specifically, this project studied the role that plant-pollinator interactions play in the organization of flowering plant communities by evaluating the different ways by which plants interact via pollinators. Knowledge on the underlying the mechanisms that mediate the assembly of these interactions is important to gain deeper understanding of the factors that influence plant species' coexistence and the processes that shape biodiversity across space and time.

The work was conducted at the UC Davis McLaughlin Biological Station in California over four years with great help from the reserve directors. So far, our study has been able to provide evidence of how co-flowering plants can simultaneously compete for pollinators, as well as increase each other's pollinator visitation (facilitation), and that these are not mutually exclusive processes in the organization of flowering communities. The study also showed that the organization of flowering plants within a single location is strongly influenced by their flowering time and floral color (and quite possibly other floral traits), which helps plants partition the available pollinator resource in ways that minimize interference with each other. 

Our results further show evidence of potential 'novel' forms of competition among plant species. For instance, we show that pollen grains from different species may compete for space on the body of pollinators as they travel between flowers, and that different pollinators may represent different competitive arenas for pollen grains. In a follow-up study we were also able to evaluate the importance of plant investment in pollen nutritional quality (pollen content), as this increases the chances of pollen dispersal to flowers of the same species. Both of these studies led to exciting new questions about the evolution of floral traits to maximize reproductive gains in plants via their male function (pollen dispersal). Ongoing studies focus on the factors that mediate interactions between pollen grains after the arrive on plant stigmas, which we hope will help to more fully understand the ecological challenges pollen grains face across their entire journey from anthers to stigmas.

Finally, our study evaluated the importance of understanding plant-pollinator interactions from the perspective of individual insects, and not just from their aggregate behavior within a species. Results from this study have revealed how the function of pollinator species within communities is determined by a variety of foraging behaviors across individual insects (bees), but that these differences can also lead to distinct consequences for the reproductive success of plants. Overall, this study has helped emphasize the importance of studying plant-pollinator interactions from the perspective of individual insects and of considering how differences in individual foraging behavior can influence overall species assembly within communities.

To date our project has contributed 12 scientific publications and over 15 presentations in scientific conferences. Our project has also contributed to the academic and professional development of more than 25 undergraduate and graduate students as well as provided the opportunity to disseminate the importance of pollination to the general public, primarily in the Tri-Cities and greater Northeast Tennessee regions.
